stem: An epidemiologist nurse is investigating a cluster of jaundice cases in a local community. Based on the provided documentation, match each statement with the most likely Hepatitis type and primary prevention strategy.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 45-year-old male. Recently attended a large banquet where several other guests reported 'stomach flu' and jaundice.
Patient 2: 22-year-old female. Reports she 'lost a needle' while sharing drugs with friends.
Patient 3: 30-year-old female. Husband was recently diagnosed with jaundice, and they do not consistently use protection during intercourse.

tabs.title: Transmission Risk Assessment
tabs.content:
PatientPrimary ExposureIncubation Phase
1Ingested raw shellfish at banquetShort (2-6 weeks)
2Parenteral (Needle-stick)Long (6-24 weeks)
3Sexual / Mucosal ContactVariable (Blood-borne)

tabs.title: Physical Findings
tabs.content: All patients present with dark urine and clay-colored stools.

rows.text: Associated with fecal-oral transmission (e.g., contaminated food/water/raw shellfish).
Associated with parenteral or sexual transmission (e.g., blood/body fluids).
Primary prevention includes hand hygiene and safe food preparation.
Primary prevention includes avoiding shared equipment and practicing safe sex.

rationale.correct: Hepatitis A (c1) is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, often linked to contaminated food sources like raw shellfish (r1). Primary prevention strategies include hand hygiene and safe food preparation (r3). Hepatitis B and C (c2) are primarily blood-borne and sexually transmitted (r2). Primary prevention focuses on avoiding contaminated needles or fluids and practicing safe sex (r4).
clinicalPearls: Mnemonic: Hep A = Vowels in the Bowels (fecal-oral route).
Mnemonic: Hep B = Blood and Body fluids.
Mnemonic: Hep C = Chronic (often associated with shared needles).

questionTrap.trap: Incorrectly associating Hepatitis B with fecal-oral transmission.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that only Hepatitis A and E are primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. Hepatitis B, C, and D are primarily blood-borne.

mnemonic.title: Hepatitis Transmission Routes
mnemonic.expansion: A (Anus/Eating - fecal-oral), B (Blood/Body fluids), C (Complications/Chronic - often via needles).
